title: What happens when everyone is a stranger?
teaser: We're more connected than ever and more isolated than ever. The loneliness is crushing. How did we get here?
framework: Matthew 6:33 - Seek first the kingdom... and all these things will be added

panels.heading: THE LONELINESS EPIDEMIC
panels.content:
You're surrounded by people and you've never felt more alone.

29% of Americans report being frequently lonely. That's not occasional isolation—that's chronic, soul-crushing loneliness.

You live in a crowded city. You work in an office full of people. You scroll through hundreds of faces every day.

But when you need someone, really need someone, the room is empty.

You thought technology would fix this. More ways to connect, more platforms to meet people, more opportunities to build community.

Instead, you got more isolation.

How did we get here?

panels.heading: THE COMMODIFICATION OF CONNECTION
panels.content:
Here's what happened: **we turned relationships into transactions.**

Every friendship became networking. Every conversation became a potential opportunity. Every connection had a hidden question: *What can you do for me?*

You curate your online presence to attract the right people. You maintain relationships that benefit your career. You drop people who stop being useful.

Relationships became a market. And you became a commodity.

But here's the cost: **when everything is transactional, nothing is intimate.**

You can't be vulnerable with people you're trying to impress. You can't be weak with people who might replace you. You can't rest with people who only value your productivity.

So you perform. And you're exhausted. And you're alone.

panels.heading: THE SEARCH FOR BELONGING
panels.content:
Deep down, you're not looking for more connections.

You're looking for **belonging.**

You want people who know your name, not just your job title. People who see you struggling and don't leave. People who stay when you're no longer useful.

You want a place where you can be fully known and still fully loved.

But you don't know where to find it.

The institutions that used to provide belonging are collapsing. Churches are empty. Civic groups are dying. Even family gatherings feel transactional.

And the digital replacements—group chats, online communities, parasocial relationships—aren't cutting it.

Because you can't build covenant through a screen.

You need actual presence. Actual commitment. Actual people.

But where?

illustration.description: Dithered image of person reaching toward distant figures, or empty chairs in a circle

panels.heading: THE ANCIENT LONGING
panels.content:
This longing isn't new.

Thousands of years ago, humans asked the same question: **Where do I belong when everything is falling apart?**

In exile, in wandering, in displacement—people searched for home.

And the answer wasn't a place. It was a people.

God didn't promise isolated individuals. He promised **a community.** A family. A covenant people bound together by something deeper than blood or transaction.

The ancient Hebrews had a phrase for it: *hesed.* Steadfast love. Loyal, unshakeable commitment.

Not based on performance. Not contingent on usefulness. Just: **You're mine. I'm staying.**

That's the kind of belonging you're searching for.

And it still exists.

panels.heading: THE INVITATION TO SOMETHING DEEPER
panels.content:
The loneliness you feel isn't a personal failure. It's a systemic collapse.

We've built a world that commodifies connection and wonders why everyone is isolated.

But here's the good news: **you're not stuck in it.**

There's another way to be human. Another way to belong.

It's ancient. It's countercultural. It's what Jesus was building when empire was collapsing.

Not a network. Not a platform. A covenant community.

People who don't leave when you stop being useful. People who stay when systems fail. People bound by *hesed*—steadfast, loyal, unshakeable love.

That's the kind of community the kingdom offers.

And you're invited into it.

panels.heading: THE INVITATION
panels.content:
God,

I'm so tired of being alone in a crowded world.

I've turned relationships into transactions and wondered why nothing feels real. I've performed for connection and ended up exhausted.

You say there's another way. A kind of belonging that isn't based on what I offer. A community that doesn't leave when I'm no longer useful.

I want that. I need that.

Show me where covenant people are. Or show me how to become one.

I'm ready to stop performing and start belonging.

Amen.
